Posts.Content: wombat23 - Gay, thanks thats reassuring and im already experiencing hot flushes so that side effect would be  nothing new, im a bit concerned about the bone/muscle  pain with letrozole as i enjoy fitness and hope it doesnt prevent me from doing this but also want to do everything i can to prevent recurrence so i do think ovary removal is the safest option for me and as you have said it doesnt appear to be a major operation to recover from! Thanks Deb xx
Posts.Title: Bilateral salpingo oopherectomy advice/side effects

Posts.Content: Optimistic - Thanks that does really help and wow 20mins and back on the ward thats impressive! I think i would be the same with the anaesthetic as i was throwing up after my previous breast surgery! Recovery time sounds ok and im experiencing hot flushes already following chemo so used to those! Its reassured me that you are ok following this surgery so thankyou for letting me know i appreciate it, Deb xx
Posts.Title: Bilateral salpingo oopherectomy advice/side effects

Posts.Content: Hi, ive discussed the option of ovary removal today due to my menopausal state being in a grey area in that im 49 and 2 different consultants have slightly different opinions, one thinking im post menopausal  and the other thinks theres a chance i may not be due to age! As my cancer gene is strongly  hormone receptive er8, pr8 i want to make sure im on the right one so ovary removal is an option and i know then il definately be post menopausal and on letrozole! Can anyone help who has had this procedure, tell me if you are glad you had it done and/or if you have any awful side effects! I already have hot flushes following chemotherapy and at the moment im taking tamoxifen with no side effects as yet? Deb x
Posts.Title: Bilateral salpingo oopherectomy advice/side effects

Posts.Content: ronstar - Thanks for your help, i totally understand your views on bone thinning, it is a concern for me too! Im on Tamoxifen at the moment but was told if im post menopausal which from the blood test i am then Letrozole would be more effective but as im 49 and they cant be sure either way then it may be the safest option for me to go with ovary removal and letrozole to try and prevent recurrence although its not an easy decision to have to make but listening to others views and experiences on here does help! X
Posts.Title: Bilateral salpingo oopherectomy advice/side effects

Posts.Content: JammyR- just to reassure you I was exactly the same a few days after the first chemo I felt like I'd got a thousand ants over my scalp and it also felt like I'd been wearing a bobble too tight in my hair the feeling when you take it out and want to give your head a good rub! I thought the cold cap had failed too but no it doesn't mean that or id have no hair by now! Not sure what it does mean but I was the same, I tried not to itch it and the silk pillowcase helped me a lot as it was cooler at night for my head! I'm day 9 2nd EC and just washed my long hair and it's still here for now although feels a lot thinner but to everyone else they can't tell any difference which is good but im a bit worried as to how much more I can lose before it becomes noticeable but for now will carry on with it, hope that helps a bit Debxx
Posts.Title: Itchy Scalp.

Posts.Content: JammyR -  Hi Joanne sorry I think I've been having issues with my phone and not getting any emails or updates from you lovely ladies! I've just come across this by trying to find latest posts! I'm sorry your hair is still shedding and its' just another awful se to deal with! You are a strong lady and with the support of gorgeous Libby and hubby you will overcome this hurdle! A work colleague of mine told me that when she did 3 x EC and 3 x T 2 years ago she said that on the 2nd T hers started to grow back so fingers crossed it won't be too long! This bc has a lot to answer for and I'm feeling the se worse as time goes on both mentally and physically and I have battled too over the last few days with it getting me down! I know I'm not alone which is the main thing but it certainly seems to get harder rather than easier at the moment! Big hugs Deb xx
Posts.Title: Hair Loss - Question about regrowth.

Posts.Content: Hi Joanne, I recall you telling me you had your lumpectomy before I was due to have my operation on 11th December which for me was left mastectomy and axillary node removal! Well I'm 11 days on after my operation and the first couple of days I was a bit sick from the anaesthetic but nothing too bad! The drains are a bit of an annoyance to carry everywhere but again nothing too bad! After the first couple of days I began doing the exercises warm up ones religiously! It' a bit sore as you would expect  but I wouldn't say i was in pain! You do feel a weird numbness in the area but I've now noticed that each day the feeling is coming back! The drains were taken out after 6 days for me and after they are removed its'  much easier to manage with showering etc and recovery. Well yesterday I went back to see the consultant who said 10 of my nodes were affected out of 30 which he removed! I was upset on hearing this news but his words were, it's  irrelevant as to the number affected as they did their job and caught the nasty stuff and you have had them all removed now! The nurse said my full range of movement in my arm is fantastic as quite often ladies are about 3 weeks ahead of me after surgery before they get to be able to get full range of movement back and now although still a little uncomfortable I am able to lie on that side and I've just been to finish the last of my Xmas shopping with no issues at all! So im sure you will be fine, they told me about blood transfusion etc as they do as a matter of routine but hey im ok and not required along with no signs of lymphodema or anything else! So from my perspective its' very do-able and not as bad as you think so enjoy Xmas and when you go your op on 27th I go to see the oncologist for the next hurdle of what treatment they are going to give me and a date when it starts! Big hugs we are in this together! Deb xxx
Posts.Title: Axillary Node Clearence

Posts.Content: Hi Lisa, I'm just ahead of you at day 7 post op! You actually have eased a couple of my worries as I like you have felt numb from the operation where I've had a left mastectomy and lymph node removal and it' a horrible sensation isn't it! Also I've felt a little stronger each day but like you after a bit of potter g about the house I've felt a bit weak, light headed and nautious so from what the other lady' on here have said it must be the anaesthetic still in our system! Your'e not on your own I'm still in absolute shock and if theres' anything I've learnt from this forum it' to try and remain positive as there are lots of ladies who have been through what we are going through and have come out the other side having kicked this monster into touch, initially I panicked terribly and got myself in such a state but having calmed down and listened to all the positive outcomes from others on here I've now realised it' a rough ride ahead with treatment but it is very treatable and we can overcome this blip in our lives, I'm 48 by the way and go back to see my consultant tomorrow to see how the surgery went and a treatment plan! Xx
Posts.Title: Day 4 post surgery

Posts.Content: Thank you, I will do and my daughter agrees about the unicorns ! X Deb
Posts.Title: Day 4 post surgery

Posts.Content: Ah Joanne, I'm sorry to hear you have to have more surgery, its' a shame they didn't take all of your nodes when they took the others! I think as you say it is a rollercoaster and you accept what you'e told but then you get further news and it' knocks you back again! Blimey I think if she had taken my pulse today it would have rocketed through the roof, bit of a silly question but I don't think people realise the enormity of this until they are in the same situation! It is really hard, but I will say the operation wasnt' as bad with recovery time as I thought it would be, from having all the axillary nodes removed too I thought recovery would be harder but I am able to have full range of movement in my arm now to which my bc nurse today was surprised at so soon as she says a lot of ladies take longer to be able to lift and use their arm as I can so my only tip I can give you after youv'e had it done is to do the exercises they give you every day, they hurt a bit at first but if you can push through the soreness you will recover quicker! What date is your op Jo? Thanks too for a bit of positivity as when he said he initially thought as it was a relatively small tumour it was grade2 and stage2 so when he said due to 10 nodes out of 30 being involved it's categorised as stage 3 I dont' think I heard much else and went into panic mode, I did hear him say he had taken it all away but just thought it meant it would come back! Over these past weeks I've never been through so many emotions! I think we both will have a better Xmas next year but for now I'm going to try and stay positive for myself and my twins and like you say they will have taken it all away so we can be thankful for that! Keep me posted and thanks again jo, big hugs xxx
Posts.Title: Post left mastectomy breast surgery results- worried

Posts.Content: Thanks Nic for sharing that, it does help to hear that you are doing well and the treatment has worked, i think my consultant thought id gone mad when he told me as i just heard stage 3 and blocked out everything else he said, luckily my husband was with me and had to calm me down by saying that he also said it's treatable and not to pay much attention to the stage3 as he said recurrence can happen to anyone at any stage but also with the treatments offered today many women never have recurrence but I didnt' digest it at the time and just broke down into tears! I think I now need to get my fighting gloves on and fight through the next year of treatment and all that comes with it and then I can be where you are, getting on with life!, it is good to be reassured by others who have been in a similar position and kicked it's ass! Thanks so much Deb x
Posts.Title: Post left mastectomy breast surgery results- worried

Posts.Content: Thanks Cathy, its good to know that it' a normal feeling after this type of surgery as I wasn't made aware of this but im sure il get used to it! Its also good to know that you are 4 years post surgery and I will be one day too Deb x
Posts.Title: Day 4 post surgery

Posts.Content: Jet999 - I'm currently using the cold cap and I'm a week into the 2nd lot of of EC chemo! Iv'e still got 60% of my long hair although it has shed all over but not that anyone else would notice it is just thinner in a ponytail, no bald patches etc! For me it's keeping a degree of normality during this horrible journey but as others have said it is a purely personal thing! Again I think the most important thing if you are going with the cold cap is to get a good tight fit making sure there are no bubbles on the crown part! Afterwards a silk pillowcase helps to stop your hair from pulling and paraben free shampoo and conditioner! I have done the cap twice now and the last time I found it a lot easier having had a couple of paracetamol beforehand, I'm not sure how much shedding there will be next time so not sure of the success of it yet but for me so far it's definately been worth doing! Deb xx
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy and cold caps

Posts.Content: Scarlettem - ah hope you and your little boy had a fab birthday and I'm sure it took your mind of the dreaded bc which is always nice! It sounds like on the hair front you are very similar to me then, I've got a missing bit by my left ear where the cap must have sat a bit wonky but only noticeable by me, I've just washed mine and strands are still coming out but not many and I've still a full covering of hair I'm just dreading the couple of days before chemo 3 which for me will be around 26th Feb! Fingers crossed this time you wont shed as much, keep me posted and il have both fingers and toes crossed for you that we remain hairy for a bit longer :-) big hugs Deb xx
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy and cold caps

Posts.Content: Scarlettem - hi can I ask, did you not shed any hair apart from above your ear? Iv'e shed quite a bit but still have a full head of hair, I've had the 2nd chemo EC now and a bit worried, I'm hoping I don't shed as much this time which for me was just before the 2nd chemo so I will see, I'm hoping I dont' shed as much this time as at present no one else would tell and not sure if it slows down or stays the same after each chemo with the cold cap! Deb xx
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy and cold caps

Posts.Content: Well one week post surgery and today I've seen the consultant who said I was now grade 3 stage 3 as my lump was only 23mm but I had 10 out of 30 lymph nodes affected which he  didnt' know until he operated! He said he had clear margins even though it sat close to the chest muscle! I had a total meltdown as I hadn't realised so many nodes were affected! I think he must have thought I was mad as I told him I needed every drug thrown at it irrespective of the side effects and was inconsolable at first! He told me the lump was small but it pushed the stage to 3 as I had 10 nodes affected! Does this mean it's more likely to come back? I see the oncologist next Wednesday for the exact treatment but he said definately chemo, radiotherapy and hormone tablets as it' her2 negative but a bit more aggressive as it' s in more nodes than first thought! Has anyone else had a similar diagnosis? Just as I thought it would be ok I'm now in turmoil again! Deb
Posts.Title: Post left mastectomy breast surgery results- worried

Posts.Content: Thanks Lisa, it is just fear of the unknown I suppose and il be thinking about you on Thursday, I'm sure it will be fine keep me posted xx
Posts.Title: Post left mastectomy breast surgery results- worried

Posts.Content: Thanks Jo I will have a look for the operation thread! For my op I was operated on at 9am and home by 5.30 same day! I did suffer a bit from the anaesthetic and was sick a couple of times and you will have a weird feeling of numbness in your underarm along with soreness but nothing awful, I'm still sore in that area a week on but nothing too bad, but yes keep doing the warm up exercises and if you have a drain as i did when that is removed do the other more strenuous arm exercises and it's fine! Im 48 years old and have an amazing husband along with 12 year old twins a son and daughter, so I've no intentions of going anywhere for some years to come, so onwards and upwards from here for us! Xx
Posts.Title: Post left mastectomy breast surgery results- worried

Posts.Content: Sash70 - Hi there, i initially had zoladex injections to suppress my ovaries, then having done some research i decided to go and have the  bilateral salpingo oopherectomy- ovary removal! I came to this decision due to the uncertainty of whether i was still pre menopausal or postmenopausal and wanted to make sure i was on the right medication which i went from tamoxifen to Letrozole post operation! The operation was straightforward 3 small incisions and was done by laparoscopy a small camera inserted etc! Post op it was a little sore for a few days but since then i havent noticed any difference as i was already having hot flushes and unable to sleep well prior to this op following chemo! Following the operation the hot sweats and insomnia is still the same but i would say the post menopausal pill letrozole does cause more achy muscles than tamoxifen but its not causing me major problems just achy limbs as though you have overdone it on the exercise! I hope this helps you a little to make a decision, if i can help you any further just ask Deb xx
Posts.Title: Ooverectomy

Posts.Content: Im the same hun, the hot flushes are far worse for me at night keeping me awake but the oopherectomy hasnt made it worse at all, ive had no side effects from the procedure and i never needed to take the painkillers i was given it was just a little sore but nothing major! I can personally say im glad i had it done and as my cancer gene was scoring 8/8 for oestrogen i just felt safer getting shot of my ovaries altogether! Let us know how you go on and what you decide, best wishes Deb xx
Posts.Title: Ooverectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Dayity it so good of you to take the time to respond it does help to hear such positive outcomes from this traumatic awful disease! I'm still a bit in shock, unable to sleep, eat or think about anything else and can't stop crying thinking it' the end! Thank you so much for sharing this with me it doesn' feel like I'm on my own x
Posts.Title: Devastated and petrified diagnosed with 2cm lobular breast cancer...

Posts.Content: Ah thankyou Kirstglo, it looks like we are in this nitemare together! I had my ct scan and they said it was clear but for me my lymph nodes were affected so I had surgery last Monday 11th and they did a left mastectomy and left axillary clearance of all my lymph nodes! You sound very positive anyway and that's what I need to be now as you're right we need to kick its' butt! I wouldnt worry too much about the lymph nodes being involved as lots of people have nodes affected and it just shows thry gave done their job and caught the nasty disease stopping the spread to other organs! Once you've had the operation you will feel better as I do a little bit now! I've learnt to stop googling and scaring myself to death! Please keep in touch and let me know how you get on, we can get through this together im sure of it! Thanks for reassuring me too, it does help to know we are not alone, big hugs to you Deb xxx
Posts.Title: Devastated and petrified diagnosed with 2cm lobular breast cancer...

Posts.Content: Sue that's amazing news to hear that you have been through it and have been cancer free for 10 years, fingers crossed it will be the same for me, thankyou for helping at this horrible time, it will help me to get through the week until I know more next Friday xx
Posts.Title: Devastated and petrified diagnosed with 2cm lobular breast cancer...

Posts.Content: Ah thanks il ask about that picc line as it' not that easy for them to get a vein on me! Im' dreading the bloody hair loss as I have long hair but just had a few inches off it! I will give the cold cap a try although I've heard its' a bit hit and miss with the success and I do need to get a wig on standby too along with a couple of beanie hats etc, its just another horrible hurdle i have to get over as you seem to be doing very positively! Thanks for the advice I'm sure il be asking you more as we go along this naff journey back to health xxx
Posts.Title: Devastated and petrified diagnosed with 2cm lobular breast cancer...

Posts.Content: Thankyou so much for sharing your journey with me, it does sound like you have had a rough year and are continuing to battle this nasty disease! I'm sure you'e right once I know that there is a plan in place to get rid of it I will feel more positive! It' just the fear of not knowing what I'm dealing with properly that my mind keeps going into overdrive and every pain or niggle I have since they told me on Friday  I'm driving myself silly thinking that it's spread everywhere else in my body and upsetting myself more! My husband is trying to keep me calm and positive but it is really hard! It really does help though to here that you have had a similar diagnosis and your scan and others have been clear! I'm so grateful to you and everyone else on here for being so kind, strong and supportive even though you are fighting your own battle! It's amazing how people pull together in times like this and support each other! I will post again once I know the outcome of my scan and what type of monster I have to share with you and hopefully be more clear and positive of what' ahead! Xxx
Posts.Title: Devastated and petrified diagnosed with 2cm lobular breast cancer...

Posts.Content: Thanks so much
Posts.Title: Devastated and petrified diagnosed with 2cm lobular breast cancer...

Posts.Content: Thanks Joanne it really has helped hearing I'm not on my own and I'm glad to hear you are starting your treatment! I think it' just fear of the unknown makes my mind run away thinking i will be told it's  the worst stage  or incurable kind as now they just know it's lobular 2.5cm malignant but will tell me the grade and type it is on Friday and the ct scan after to see if it's spread anywhere else! I know I've got to stay strong and it really does help to here your journey  to make me kick myself up the bum to stop crying and thinking the worst and get myself to be more positive and as you say take my mind off it with entertaining the children, thanks again Joanne x
Posts.Title: Devastated and petrified diagnosed with 2cm lobular breast cancer...

Posts.Content: Helen, that is so comforting to hear as yes I've been fine from finding the lump in my armpit 4 months ago until just finding the lump in my breast! I was initially told by the gp the lymph node in my armpit was nothing to worry about so hence 4 months later the lump has appeared in my breast! I now realise this lymph node was a warning signal but only realised now and hopefully in time! It' fab that you managed to kick cancer into touch and with support from people like yourself I will hopefully do the same, it' just waiting to hear what I'm dealing with as at the moment every bit of aches in my back or niggle in my body in now thinking the worst! Thanks for the support it does help to hear that it' not all doom and gloom xx
Posts.Title: Devastated and petrified diagnosed with 2cm lobular breast cancer...

Posts.Content: Hi Jellita, thanks for the message, it' been a bit of a rollercoaster ride the last couple of weeks, I've made myself physically sick with worry! There was a relief to hear my ct scan was clear although they said there were a couple of nodules on my thyroid although they said were not connected to my cancer diagnosis! I've had surgery last Monday 11th Dec where they did left mastectomy and removal of all lymph nodes and I should start chemo etc shortly, I go back to see the consultant on Tuesday next week who I think will have a treatment plan and give me more details about the grade 2 her2 negative diagnosis which i dont really understsnd very well! Have you been in a similar position? Xx
Posts.Title: Devastated and petrified diagnosed with 2cm lobular breast cancer...

Posts.Content: Oh you are a little ahead of me then! Are you using the cold cap during the chemo as I'm hoping that will help with saving some hair at least and any other tips for my chemo would be great if you have any! Thanks Deb x
Posts.Title: Devastated and petrified diagnosed with 2cm lobular breast cancer...

Posts.Content: Hi, I was diagnosed yesterday with a 2cm lobular cancerous lump in my left breast following finding a painful lump (lymph node) in my armpit! Both are cancerous having had ultrasound and biopsy and I'm now awaiting a ct scan! I'm totally devastated, petrified and keep thinking life is over and i hope it hasnt spread I have 2 young children and have to wait another week for the ct scan and treatment plan! Has anyone been in a similar position to me and recovered? Im finding it hard to cope with this news andcso is my husband we have 2 young children I'm out of my mind with worry! Help Signature
Posts.Title: Devastated and petrified diagnosed with 2cm lobular breast cancer...

Posts.Content: Wow Carolyn you have been through a rough time but to hear that you have come through the other side and are still here and fighting this cruel disease is inspiring and really does give me some positive feelings! I'm finding it so difficult having to wait only a week so in comparison to you that's not long at all but as you say a day of not knowing the full diagnosis feels like a week it's unbearable! My hubby has gone to get me some nytol to help me get some much needed sleep, I think I'm not coping as well as perhaps others because I lost my mum to aggressive lung cancer and she passed away after 3 months of being diagnosed along with her twin brother who also died from oesophagus cancer 3 years later, so i know they are different but having gone through the journey with them ive just seen it as my turn and it's knocked me for 6 and I'm finding it hard not to think it's incurable like theirs! Thank you so much for sharing your journey Carolyn it' so kind of you and really does give me hope that I will see my children grow up, if it's ok I will update you and other truly kind inspirational people who have replied to me next week after my c.t scan etc xx
Posts.Title: Devastated and petrified diagnosed with 2cm lobular breast cancer...

Posts.Content: Joanne forgot to say hope all goes well with the surgery xx
Posts.Title: Devastated and petrified diagnosed with 2cm lobular breast cancer...

Posts.Content: Thankyou so much for the support and it is helping me hearing that there is light at the end of this terrifying tunnel, I'm so glad you are doing well, fingers crossed my scan etc will go ok too, I've managed to force some soup into me and I will try and stay strong and positive and give myself a fighting chance, thanks again xx
Posts.Title: Devastated and petrified diagnosed with 2cm lobular breast cancer...

Posts.Content: Dayityrose - I'm so bloody sorry you have this to deal with again but I know how strong you are and you have noticed this straight away  and so should have been caught very early and is being dealt with so try not to worry even though I know it's easy to say as you know how I was and you helped me no end when I was diagnosed! So angry I would be too definately as its' not the news any of us want to hear after going thru this shitty treatment but you will overcome whatever this is and you don't know yet! Dayity I'm sending you lots of love and virtual hugs and get those hobnail boots on and kick whatever this thickening is to the kerb, you know you can lovely lady and we are with you all the way! Deb xxxxx
Posts.Title: Thickening in right boob

Posts.Content: Dayityrose - Fantastic news, I've replied to you privately too but I'm so relieved for you, its' so good to hear news like this and can't tell you how much it's cheered me up at the min as this chemo journey is really getting me down so just what I needed to hear! You are a fabulous strong lady and have well and truly kicked bc to the kerb! Those hob nail boots have served you well :-) Big hugs Deb xxx
Posts.Title: Thickening in right boob

Posts.Content: Dayityrose - I had similar diagnosis as you so you are my leading star, I'm sure it will be absolutely fine and they will be just being extra careful and if it is anything it will be fixable so chin up lovely we've all got your back and I've got my fingers and toes crossed for Wednesday,  yes please let us know how it goes but in the meantime kick the worry to the kerb xxx
Posts.Title: Thickening in right boob

Posts.Content: Hi, I think it' nearly a week since I last posted on here! I was told that I have 2.5cm lump in my left breast and infected lymph node in left armpit, I've had ct scan and biopsies of both lump and lymph node and waiting to see the consultant on Friday! It' s obviously devastated me and since having this news I've been very upset crying and now  had back ache, felt sick etc, did anyone else have these symptoms through stress as I'm now convincing myself that it's spread as before this week I was fine and I'm dreading hearing terrible news! Help
Posts.Title: Stressed/Anxious

Posts.Content: Thanks so much Sue, after looking at the message you sent me before it does give me hope that I can get through this, I just keep getting pain in between my shoulders and bottom of my back and these awful frightening thoughts make me feel sick convincing myself that it's spread, my husband keeps telling me it's stress but it is so hard, I just wish I could be stronger and more positive but not much longer to go through the agony of not knowing x
Posts.Title: Stressed/Anxious

Posts.Content: Thanks Alison, it' reassuring to know I'm not on my own as I'm crying a lot of the time and getting so worked up thst my neck shoulders and back go so tense I'm stressing myself out! I know I will be an emotional wreck later today petrified of what they are going to say, but need to know also! Fingers crossed it will be ok, thanks again for getting in touch, Debbie xx
Posts.Title: Stressed/Anxious

Posts.Content: Thanks Jolene that is a comfort to hear, I'm driving myself crazy with worry so it' such a help to feel I'm not on my own through this trauma! I'm on my way shortly to hear the full diagnosis  but as you have been through the same you will have felt sick to the stomach the same as I do right now! Thanks for the support, Debbie x
Posts.Title: Stressed/Anxious

Posts.Content: Thankyou so much, I'm sure with help from you and other strong women on here I will get through, you are so kind to take time out to reply to make things a bit easier to bear xxx
Posts.Title: Stressed/Anxious

Posts.Content: Thankyou, I'm sure i come across as a complete paranoid wimp and in some respects I am! I think I'm worse as my mum had horrific back pain before being diagnosed with lung cancer and is sadly no longer here! My husband keeps telling me it' s stress pain and to stop panicking! Thankyou it does help to hear from people whove bern in the same position who understands what im going through! I thought I was a healthy, fit and relatively strong confident person before this bombshell hit! I had to go for a run this morning to convince myself I'm not totally disease ridden ! Thankyou for your comforting words I will take heed and stop panicking x
Posts.Title: Stressed/Anxious

Posts.Content: Hi Sara, I've not got occult breast cancer but invasive ductal cancer of the left breast! The similar thing is that I didn' have a lump in the breast initially, I first found a lump in my armpit which was painful and having been told it was nothing to worry about by the gp I left it for a few months and then noticed a small lump in my breast which then turned out to be cancer and in turn they said there was lymph node involvement in my armpit! So in a way similar in that the lymph nodes were doing their job to catch the sneaky disease! I was diagnosed on 24th November and 11th December I had left mastectomy for the lump which was 23mm and removal of all lymph nodes 10 out of 30 were positive! I'm  now due to start chemotherapy on Tuesday next week which scares me the most as the surgery I found quite do -able! We are all in this together and I'm here if you need to talk along with all these other lovely ladies! Deb xx
Posts.Title: Primary occult breast cancer - anyone else??

Posts.Content: Thanks Sara, I am feeling a bit nervous about chemo tomorrow! Im' glad you have got sorted today and not feeling too sicky now! I think they are giving me a tablet an hour before chemo as I struggled with sickness from the anaesthetic from the operation along with other anti sickness meds so I'm hoping that will help but I've not got a strong stomach so we will see also not sure if the cold cap will cause a bit of sickness with how cold it might be! My chemo is the EC first then 3 cycles of the F bit! I will keep you posted Sara and I'm sure we will both kick it's ass into touch xx
Posts.Title: Primary occult breast cancer - anyone else??

Posts.Content: Hi, when I asked the surgeon told me that everyone has different amounts of lymph nodes from anything from 5 in some people to 42 in others! I had 10 affected and I had a total of 30! So in my case he removed all, did you ask how many you had in total as to how many he removed? My breast care nurse was well clued up on my operation too so maybe if your concerned I'd just give the breast care nurse a call but I'm sure if there was any chance of risk they would have removed all that were necessary, I'm a stress head though so I would be the same and id definately just to ease your mind ask them the question xx
Posts.Title: Primary occult breast cancer - anyone else??

Posts.Content: Hi Taralou, my diagnosis is similar to yours with lymph node involvement and im now 10 days after my first Ec-t and I've found the more the days go by the better and I've not found it too bad either apart from the first day where I was nauseous but following taking the sickness meds I've been fine since day 1 so fingers crossed it will continue  throughout this treatment! Im' just waiting to see if the cold cap has been successful on my hair! Keep us posted big hugs Deb x
Posts.Title: 1st chemo session yesterday!!

Posts.Content: Hi Taralou, my diagnosis is similar to yours with lymph node involvement and im now 10 days after my first Ec-t and I've found the more the days go by the better and I've not found it too bad either apart from the first day where I was nauseous but following taking the sickness meds I've been fine since day 1 so fingers crossed it will continue  throughout this treatment! Im' just waiting to see if the cold cap has been successful on my hair! Keep us posted big hugs Deb x
Posts.Title: 1st chemo session yesterday!!

Posts.Content: Hi, I can completely relate to how you are feeling, since I was diagnosed 24th November with a lump and lymph node involvement I was certain it had spread everywhere as I had horrendous back pain and neck pain! I then had a ct scan and mri scan which were all clear! Following the operation the back and neck pain subsides for a while then I've noticed when I've got upset and worried it comes back and nothing including doing epsom salt baths worked for me other than thinking positive, so as others have said its' more likely to be stress related! Ive tried to be more positive as i was making myself ill with worry thinking it had spread even though the scans were clear which just made my aches and pains worse! We can do this and I've found the ladies on here massively supportive! Deb xx
Posts.Title: Secondaries
